Jharkhand gets first Haj house as it rea.description: RANCHI: Police in Ranchi have made elaborate preparations for peaceful Eid celebrations across the city on Wednesday. Sensitive areas with history of communal clashes have been identified for deployment of additional security forces throughout the day. Talking to TOI, senior superintendent of police (Ranchi) Anish Gupta said: "A total of 20 quick response teams will be on the go around the city to maintain the law and order during the celebration. Jharkhand Armed Police, Rapid Action Force, Reserve Auxiliary Battalion, Indian Reserve Battalion and home guards have been deployed across the city to keep a tab on the developments and to avoid any untoward incident." A mock drill was also conducted by the RAF personnel at Ranchi Police Lines on Tuesday evening in the presence of city SP S Veenapani, rural SP Ashutosh Shekhar and other RAF officials. Last year, a clash erupted in Hindpiri area ahead of Eid when a motorcyclist participating in a political rally accidentally hit a woman shopping in the market, triggering a series of violent events. "We will keep a strict watch on the sensitive areas in the city," Gupta added. The stretch between Kali Mandir Chowk and Ratan Talkies Chowk in the city has also been barricaded with entry of vehicular traffic barred from Monday morning for the Eid market on the stretch. People stepped out in large numbers to buy gifts, food items and clothes for the celebration. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Bidyut gets highest votes from Jamshedpu.description: JAMSHEDPUR: Riding on Modi tsunami, the BJP candidate from Jamshedpur seat, Bidyut Baran Mahato, created history in the 17th Lok Sabha polls. Mahato won the seat by a record margin of 3,01,033 votes. After the formation of Jamshedpur seat in 1957 (earlier it was Malbhum South seat), Baran has secured the highest number of votes (6,76,894), while the mahagathbandhan candidate from JMM, Champai Soren, got 3,75,861 votes. It may be mentioned here that Mahato was the sitting candidate from the seat. In the 2014 polls, Mahato had defeated Ajoy Kumar, then in JVM-P, by 99,876 votes. Mahato had then polled 4,64,153 votes and the polling percentage was 66.33%. In the recently held general elections, the voting percentage for Jamshedpur seat was a record 67.09%, which is the highest ever. Mahato, who had earlier got 44.24% of the total votes polled, received 59.4% of the votes this time around. In the 2011 bypoll for the Jamshedpur seat, BJP candidate Dineshanand Goswami was defeated by JVM-P candidate Ajoy Kumar, who is now Jharkhand Congress chief. Goswami got only 16.33% votes and Kumar got 37.38%. The voting percentage was 52.93%. In the 1962 general elections, CPI candidate Udaykar Mishra defeated Congress candidate N C Mukherjee by just 19,805 votes. The polling percentage was 41.75. In the next parliamentary polls in 1967, the voting percentage rose to 47.34%. S C Prasad of Congress polled 75,219 votes and he defeated CPM’s U Mishra by 40,702 votes. In the 1971 LS polls, the voting percentage fell to 29.98 and Congress candidate Sardar Swarna Singh defeated CPI’s Kedar Das by just 206 votes, which is the narrowest-winning margin from the seat till date. In the post-Emergency 1977 polls, Bharatiya Lok Dal candidate Rudra Pratap Sarangi defeated Congress’s heavyweight candidate V G Gopal by 63,753 votes. Between 1980 and 1996 LS polls, the voting percentage ranged between 48.43% and 59.2%. It was during the Atal Bihar Vajpayee era that the voting percentage in Jamshedpur seat shot up to 62.41% in the 1998 polls. BJP candidate Abha Mahato defeated independent candidate and former chairman-cum-MD of TISCO Russy Mody by 97,433 votes. Abha was the first woman MP from the Jamshedpur seat. After 1998, the voting percentage graph hovered between 54.74% and 56.59%, and it rose to 66.33% in the 2014 general elections. --eom Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Six Maoists surrender in Dumka.description: DUMKA: At a time when Jharkhand is witnessing a sudden spurt in violence triggered by Left-wing extremists, six Maoist rebels, including two women, surrendered before officials of the district police and Sahastra Seema Bal at an event organized at the Dumka SP Y S Ramesh’s office on Monday. Police said the families of these surrendered rebels were in touch with them for long before they finally gave up arms. The rebels alos habnded over five weapons, including one AK-47, one Insas rifle, one rifle, one carbine, and a pistol to the police. Ramesh said all the weapons were looted from security forces in the past. The six — Sukhlal Dehri, Pici Di alias Prishila Devi, Premshila alias Hopan Di, Kiran Tudu alias Pakku Tudu, Bhagat Singh Hembrom and Siddo Marandi — hail from Dumka and Pakur districts. Police said they had escaped from the rebel outfit after the death of zonal commander Sahdeo Rai alias Tala Da in an encounter with security forces on January 13. Of the six who surrendered today, four are couples. While Pici Di is married to Sukhlal, Premshila is in relationship with Siddo and delivered a baby six months ago. Ramesh said these couples will be kept in an open jail Hazaribag so that they can lead a family life until the disposal of the cases against them. “These Maoists approached the police through their families for surrendering. They finally surrendered after they were assured of getting proper rehabilitation as per the state's surrender policy, which is the best in the country,” Ramesh said. He said that baring Sukhlal Dehri and Premshila, four of these rebels were involved in the 2013 Kathikund ambush in which the then Pakur SP Amarjit Balihar was killed along with his guards. Kiran alias Pakku Tudu, who joined rebel outfit in 2010, is a widow of the dreaded zonal commander Sahdeo Rai, said police. “After having experienced the miseries of leading a tough life wandering in jungles, living under constant threats, I decided to surrender. I once urged Tala to surrender. However, he remained indifferent and ultimately died of a police bullet,” said Kiran, who was a sub-zonal commander of the rebel outfit and carried a reward of Rs5 lakh. As many as 16 cases are lodged against her in different police stations of Dumka. Pici Di said that top ranking male rebels often sexually exploited women cadres. “The top leadership of Maoists never shared any details of levy that was collected, leave aside fulfilment of other promises made to us while we were inducted into the outfit. Women cadres often had to face sexual exploitation at the hands of top ranking male Maoists,” said Pici Di, also a sub-zonal commander with Rs5 lakh reward on her head. Cricket craze keeps fans indoors.description: JAMSHEDPUR/RANCHI: The Steel City experienced a near-total shutdown for the better part of Sunday as most residents stayed indoors watching the faceoff between traditional rivals India and Pakistan in the Cricket World Cup (CWC). Amid apprehension of bad weather in England playing spoilsport, fans in the industrial town kept their fingers crossed hoping that the match will be held. “This match has generated tremendous excitement, as it is being played just four months after India and Pakistan were on the brink of a war in February following the terror attack in Pulwama,” former Cricketer’s Association functionary S N Pathak said. Former Ranchi university player, Neeraj Chauhan, said a India and Pakistan match is always a hit with the fans. “The CWC comes every four years, and it is a delight to watch the two nations play,” a 37-year-old junior engineer, Tarkeshwar Kumar, who adjusted his weekly-off to watch the match, said. “The excitement that builds up over an India-Pakistan encounter is inexplicable,” ex-cricketer Supriyo Bose, while watching the match with friends at a club in Kadma, said. On the flip side, markets experienced a dip in footfall owing to the match. “During summer, business is brisk in the evening hours but due to the cricket match, the market is dull today,” Mohamed Feroz, who owns a cosmetic shop in Bistupur, said. Film buffs, too, decided to remain glued to the TV sets due to which cinema halls received relatively less booking. “Normally, Sundays witness full house bookings but today the response is nearly 50% down,” an employee at a multiplex in Jamshedpur said on Sunday. The response of the booking staff at Payal Cinema, which is a single screen theatre, was the same. The roads wore a deserted look in Mahendra Singh Dhoni’s home town, too. On Sunday morning, cricket fans performed a havan at Pahari Baba temple in Ranchi to pray for India’s victory. A group of Muslim fans offered a chadar at Risaldar mazar in Doranda. Uttam Yadav, who led the special puja and havan at Pahari mandir, said on Sunday morning, “We are rooting for a special show from Dhoni. Hope he gets enough opportunity to wield his willow.” Mahi, however, got out after scoring a solitary run. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Priyanka Gandhi.description: RAE BARELI: In her scathing attack on BJP and Modi government, Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi said that Congress doesn't need any certificate from anyone to prove its nationalist feelings. "Ye brashtachar ki baat karnewale sabse bade brashta hain… kaam ki baat karte hain magar sabse bade nikamme hain… dharma ki baat karne wale sabse bada adharm kar rahe hain - dharm ka istemal kar rahe hain… saheedon ka istemal kar rahe hain - sirf rajinit ke liye (They are talking of acting against corruption but are corrupt themselves… they talk of work but are good for nothing… they talk of dharma (read duties) but indulge in adharma by defying its norms - they use religion and martyrs for political interests)," Priyanka stated in her closed door meeting with cadres on Thursday. The Congress leader hit out at BJP's strategy of playing the nationalist card. "We are Congress… we launched the freedom movement… gave our blood and sweat… braved British atrocities … we don't need any certificate to prove our nationalist feelings especially from the ones who apologised to the British at that time", asserted Priyanka, urging the workers to go to every household in their area and meet every voter. She directed the workers to apprise the voters that the 2019 Lok Sabha election was as important as the freedom movement. Infusing energy in them she said, "Don't be afraid of anything as this is a weak government. Only a weak government curbs the voice of the people, which is a crime in democracy." Priyanka asked the workers to stand up for their leader whose only dream is the progress of India and its people. "Rahul thinks of the people without any vested interest," Priyanka said citing the example of her conversation with Rahul on the issue of using self-help group women for campaigning. "When I proposed to him this idea, he simply denied… saying that I created the SHGs to empower women, not use them in any way," Priyanka said quoting her brother. The Congress general secretary told the workers that she was working on mission 2022. "We will, with your support, form the government in 2022. And once we come, we will stay here for long on the basis of our hard work," she said adding that the hard-workers would be adequately rewarded. Summer Season.description: NEW DELHI: Google on Friday celebrated the longest day of the year in Northern Hemisphere by dedicating a doodle. Also called summer solstice, or midsummer, the longest day occurs when one of the Earth's poles has its maximum tilt toward the Sun. What: The longest day (and shortest night) of the year in the Northern Hemisphere. When: Today (June 21). Technically, the solstice occurs when the sun is directly over the imaginary Tropic of Cancer or 23.5°N latitude. In 2019, this will occur at 3:54 pm GMT on Friday (or 9:24 pm IST). Why: The term 'solstice' comes from Latin —'sol' means sun and 'sistere' means to stand still. How: The 23.4° tilt in the Earth's axis causes varying amounts of sunlight to reach different regions during its year-long orbit around the Sun. Today, the North Pole is tipped more towards the Sun than on any other day of the year. However, that does not mean more heat or that the Earth is any closer to the Sun, per common misconceptions. Which: Summer solstices happen twice each year (once in each hemisphere). Summer solstice for the Northern Hemisphere = Winter solstice for the Southern Hemisphere, and vice-versa. Also, during Equinoxes (vernal and autumnal), the Sun shines directly on the Equator and the length of day and night are nearly equal in either hemisphere. Key dates for 2019 (Northern Hemisphere)Spring Equinox: Wednesday, March 20 Summer Solstice: Friday, June 21 Autumn Equinox: Monday, September 23 Winter Solstice: Sunday, December 22 FYI: The longest day of the year was the reason why Narendra Modi chose June 21 as the International Day of Yoga. Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. AAP plans signature campaign to highligh.description: RANCHI: Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) announced on Friday that it will collect 25,000 signatures and send them to the Prime Minister's Office to draw attention to electricity and water woes faced by the residents in capital city. The signature campaign will be carried out through 'mohalla sabhas' here. The regional secretary of AAP, Rajan Kumar Singh, said, "We will gherao Raj Bhavan on June 12 to demand a resolution to the problems." AAP's state unit also demanded that electricity companies be fined if there are any unscheduled power cuts. Singh added, "On an average, every day there are about 4 to 5 hours of power cut in Ranchi." The party, which withdrew its Jamshedpur candidate Dinesh Mahato after allegations of corruption surfaced against him, is planning to contest all 81 seats in the forthcoming Vidhan Sabha elections in the state. The acute water crisis in Ranchi had taken a violent turn on Thursday when Bharat Prasad Sahu, a resident of Kishoreganj, injured six people, including a woman, at Bhuiyan Toli over water distribution. Station in-charge of Kotwali police station S N Mandal said, "Two FIRs have been registered. The accused and the victims are undergoing treatment in hospitals at the moment." The youth wing of JVM-P also sat on a dharna at Firayalal Chowk to protest against water scarcity in the city. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

App connect for schools in Ranchi.description: RANCHI: Keeping a tab on a child’s performance and day-to-day activities in school has become increasingly challenging for parents given the fast-paced lifestyle. Moreover, as the number of working parents increases, it has become even more difficult of them to make their children follow proper study hours. In view of the difficulties faced by the parents and guardians, schools in Ranchi have moved on from websites and introduced dedicated mobile applications for information dissemination. Most schools in the city now have their own android apps developed with a log-in feature for students and their parents to check attendance, marks obtained and extracurricular performance along with GPS tracking facility for school buses. While some of these apps are home grown by IT teams in the respective schools, some are developed through Delhi and Mumbai-based tech support agencies. In March this year, city-based Sarala Birla Public School introduced an app titled Gavaaksh, which is available on Google Playstore. The school’s principal, Paramjeet Kaur, said, “Everything from the attendance of a child to his or her marks scored in any examination are updated on the app for convenience of the parents. We also have a feature where every activity of a student in the school — be it a pat on the back for an extra-curricular achievement or an incident of indiscipline, is updated. This helps the parents to stay in touch with what is happening with their child right from their homes.” Another prominent school — Oxford Public School — was one of the early schools to embrace this trend in mid-2018 by launching its own app named after the institute. Principal Suraj Sharma said the app is being developed by a Delhi-based firm and they are in the process of introducing a variety of new features. He said, “Some of the aspects like teacher’s login and bus tracking system among others are being explored to make this app more relevant for both the school and the parents.” Many schools also have a separate mobile-based application for tracking their buses from the time they leave the campus till every students is safely dropped at his or her home. Sapphire International School admission counsellor, Kunal Prasad, said, “Through our online Vidyalaya app, parents can not only track their wards’ performance in the school, but they can also locate the buses when they are out to drop the students through the GPS tracking system. It is a safety measure introduced for both the parents and the students with an intention to help the parents plan their pick-ups according to the location of the buses.” Other schools like Bishop Westcott School (for boys and girls), Delhi Public School, Ranchi, and St Thomas School also have their dedicated apps introduced in the past one year to keep parents in the loop about their wards’ activity and performance. Parents said these apps have made their lives easier. Ajay Rai, president of the Jharkhand Abhibhavak Manch, and father of two girls, said, “Introduction of such apps definitely has made the parent participation far more active and the student’s school activity is much more transparent as now. We can learn all about our children with the click of a button. For parents who teach their children at home without taking private tutions, it is also a great work to keep a tab on the course work and homework for the students.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Skywalk: Yay or nay? Write to PWD.description: RANCHI: State government has sought public opinion on one of Raipur's most controversial projects - the Skywalk at Shastri Chowk. Public Works Department (PWD) has asked public to send in their views whether the Skywalk should be completed or demolished or put to some other use. The department has requested the residents to send in their suggestions by post or mail till June 15,2019. To do so, people can drop their letters in the suggestion box at PWD office or write to 'Executive Engineer, PWD Sirpur Bhawan Campus, Behind Aakashwani' or send an e-mail to skywalkraipur@gmail.com between June 1 to June 15. The project, conceived and implemented during Raman Singh-led BJP regime, is almost complete. Chief minister Bhupesh Baghel had hinted that the government would take public's opinion on the utility of the project. Congress had earlier opposed the Skywalk project at Shashtri Chowk - which was supposed to connect important roads at prime locations and easy congestion on the busy lane. Since its conception, the project has attracted criticism with residents call it a waste of public money. They complained, they preferred a flyover for regulating traffic instead of a massive ramp built for the pedestrians. The decision on the project had been pending due to the model code of conduct put in place due to the Lok Sabha elections. The estimated budget of Skywalk project is around Rs50 crore. While highlighting the disadvantage of the project, executive engineer of public works department said, "The landing of the six lanes will obstruct roads and restrict the scope of road widening in the future." Earlier in a press conference held at Rajiv Bhawan, chief minister Baghel had said that the projects which do not have people's support, but are on the verge of completion need attention and detailed study. Talking to TOI, PWD Minister Tamradhwaj Sahu had said, "Though the Skywalk was constructed for the use of pedestrians drew flak since its inception, hence we need time to address the issue and conclude its status of existence." Day after blasts, 13 IEDs & detonators s.description: RANCHI/DALTONGANJ: A day after 26 security personnel were injured in a series of IED blasts triggered by Maoists in Seraikela, 13 IEDs were recovered from a cave at Bagsara near Pipra's Seerniya Dam during a police-CRPF joint operation. Apart from the IEDs, the forces recovered 11 gelatin sticks, 250 metres of codex wire, 200 metres of electric wire and two black uniforms. Five rounds of ammunition and eight rifles were also recovered, but were not found in working condition, police said. "All these were dumped in a cave by the CPI (Maoist) operatives, only to be used for violence during the recently held Lok Sabha elections. But they could not because of heavy security arrangements made this time," said A D Sharma, commandant of CRPF's 134 battalion. Police said the cave where these explosives were found is frequented by top Maoists Nitesh Yadav, Abhijit Yadav and Sita Ram Rajwar. A cache of explosives and weapons was also recovered in February from this area. Of the 26 security personnel who were injured in Tuesday's blasts, 11 were discharged after treatment at a private hospital in Ranchi later in the evening. Two more were discharged on Wednesday morning. The remaining 13 are undergoing treatment at the hospital, which has called in experts from a specialized eye hospital to carry out surgical processes on eight of the jawans who have received splinter injury in their eyes. Five patients are on ventilator, but are said to be stable. "Anuj Kumar (Jharkhand Jaguar) and Mohammed Rehman (CRPF) have been discharged today as doctors found them fit enough to get back home. Dulal Das, one of the security personnel underwent an eye surgery on Tuesday and a team of doctors from Shankara Netralaya is going to visit on Wednesday evening to review his condition. Rest are responding well to the medication and are out of danger," said Anand Srivastava, the spokesperson of Bhagwan Mahavir Medica Superspecialty Hospital Ranchi. Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Bidyut takes oath in Bangla, makes Benga.description: Bengalis living in Jamshedpur are elated that local BJP MP Bidyut Baran Mahato took oath in the Parliament in Bangla. Talking TOI from Delhi on Thursday, Bidyut said: “I have always worked for the development of Bengali, so taking oath in this language makes me feel proud. I studied at a Bengali-medium school and my parents too speak in the same language at home.” He said his love for the language is not new. When he was a Baharagora MLA from JMM, he had taken oath in the assembly in Bengali. Mahato said large parts of Jamshedpur seat were earlier under the Manbhum south seat. He also said tribals living in this part of Jharkhand are very close to Bengalis and marriage between two are very common. He also promised that as an MP he would ensure that Bengali gets its due status in Jharkhand. Notably, Jamshedpur was carved out of Manbhum, which was a part of Bengal. In 1957, the Jamshedpur Lok Sabha constituency was created. Historians say at one time 96% population living in Manbhum spoke in Bengali. Senior orthopedic surgeon from TMH Indranil Bhaduri said: “As a probashi Bengali (Bengalis living outside Bengal), I was overjoyed to hear that our MP took oath in Bengli,” adding that it would make Bengalis living here feel that their mother tongue is getting due respect. President of Jamshedpur Bengali Association Tapas Mitra also hailed Mahato’s move. Mitra said Mahato has a soft corner for Bengali-speaking people living in and around Jamshedpur Lok Sabha constituency. Shatarupa Mukherjee, a student of mass communication at Jamshedpur Women's College and a first-time voter, also expressed pride. Members of the Jamshedpur Bengali Community, a Facebook group, was full of praise for the MP. Cutting across party lines noted city-based industrialist and once JVM-P candidate for Jamshedpur MP seat Bikas Mukherjee said Mahato has always ensured that Bangla as a language gets its due respect. Talking from Istanbul, Mukherjee, who is associated with city Bengali association and The Bengal Club expressed his happiness in this regard. Echoing similar sentiments, senior science teacher at Loyola School Debjyoti Bose, he felt great that Mahato took oath in Bangla and was confident that Bengalis living in this city for many generations would share similar feelings. Sougata Lahiri, born in Jamshedpur now working in Kolkata, said with the passage of time Bangla-medium schools had downed their shutters in the Steel City due to lack of students and non-availability of study material, but the move undertaken by Mahato raised hopes that the closed schools would be opened in the near future. Jharkhand doctors express solidarity wit.description: RANCHI/BOKARO: Around 700 students and junior doctors of three medical colleges along with doctors at various private healthcare facilities lent their support to their counterparts in West Bengal, who are on strike against violence faced by them. From organising street plays, to wearing helmets with placards in hand and raising slogans against West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee, the doctors and students from across the state protested against the violence inflicted upon their counterparts at a state-run medical college in West Bengal. The agitators demanded a healthy and secure work environment from the government. Several undergraduate students, who participated in plays, highlighted the importance of doctors and their importance in serving the society. “On several occasions we receive patients who had undertaken medication from quacks for months and approach us at the end. It becomes very difficult to save such patients and then it becomes a reason for patient’s kin to thrash us. We are only trying to send a message that we are doctors we aren’t gods. Please don’t punish us for saving a life as it happened at NRS Kolkata,” said Smita Mishra, a third year MBBS student of RIMS Ranchi. Medicos from Jamshedpur’s Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College and Hospital and Dhanbad’s Pataliputra Medical College and Hospital also held demonstrations on their respective campuses. Around 6,000 patients were affected as outpatient departments, indoor services and elective operation theatres were shut across the state bringing health services to a standstill as doctors protested demanding security. Apart from government doctors, medicos at private hospitals too wore black badges on their arms and attended to patients in support of the protests. A candle march was taken out in the evening by doctors from the city at RIMS campus were medical professionals participated under the aegis of Indian Medical Association (IMA), Jharkhand chapter. General secretary of state IMA, Pradeep Kumar Singh said: “We have been demanding protection which is not only beneficial for doctors but also safeguards patients’ rights, for past two years, but it is still stuck in the state legislative assembly. How can doctors feel secure if state government keeps on failing us?” The protest saw maximum participation from junior doctors across the state and their main concern was they are always at the receiving end as they are the primary contact with the patients and their relatives. The doctors at Bokaro General Hospital who also participated in the protest spoke to TOI and raised their issues. “We look after patients round the clock as senior doctors only pay visits, but we get thrashed by patients’ kin as it happened with the intern in the West Bengal hospital. Doctors are feeling threatened and that is affecting their morale in serving people,” said Shweta, a junior doctor, at BGH. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
